CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domesic remedies);Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 13;Violations of Art. 3 (substantive aspect);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is currently serving a prison sentence in correctional colony no . CARDINAL in GPE .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was convicted of drug trafficking and sentenced to DATE imprisonment . In DATE he was granted an early release .

CARDINAL . In DATE the police received an anonymous complaint stating that the applicant and his friend Mr O. were making and selling drugs in their flats . The police questioned the applicant 's neighbours , who confirmed unanimously that the applicant and Mr O. were drug dealers .

CARDINAL . NORP The police made a series of test purchases of drugs from the applicant and Mr O. In DATE and DATE two persons code - named “ Shadow ” and “ NORP ” asked the applicant and Mr O. to make drugs for them . They went on several occasions to Mr O. 's flat accompanied by their acquaintance PERSON The applicant and PERSON made opium from the ingredients bought by the applicant with Shadow 's and PERSON 's money . They then consumed the opium together .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON called the applicant , complained of withdrawal symptoms and asked him to procure him drugs . The applicant asked PERSON to take MONEY from GPE and to change it in a nearby pharmacy . He then bought opium ingredients with that money and made opium in his flat . He met GPE TIME , handed a part of the opium over to him and left the remainder for himself . PERSON gave the opium received from the applicant to the police .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and charged with drug trafficking .

CARDINAL . During the trial the Proletarskiy District Court of Tula heard numerous witnesses , including Shadow , PERSON , the applicant 's neighbours and the police officers who had supervised the test purchases . PERSON 's pre - trial depositions were read out as he had died before the start of the trial . The trial court also examined expert opinions and material evidence , such as the opium received by Shadow and PERSON from the applicant and Mr O. and utensils for making opium found in the applicant 's and PERSON flats .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG acquitted the applicant of drug trafficking in respect of the episodes of DATE and DATE , finding that on those occasions he had made drugs for personal consumption with his acquaintances rather than for sale . It further convicted the applicant of drug trafficking for selling drugs on DATE . The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment on appeal .
CARDINAL . From DATE to CARDINAL DATE the applicant was held in remand centre no . IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL in GPE .

CARDINAL . According to certificates of DATE issued by the remand centre administration and submitted by the ORG , from DATE to CARDINAL DATE the applicant was held in cell no . DATE , which measured QUANTITY m and housed CARDINAL forty inmates . From DATE to DATE he was held in cell no . DATE , which measured QUANTITY m and housed CARDINAL inmates . From DATE to CARDINAL DATE he was held in cell no . CARDINAL , measuring QUANTITY m and housing CARDINAL forty inmates . The Government also produced the plan of those cells confirming the cell measurements .

CARDINAL . The same certificates state that the inmates were allowed to take a shower once DATE for TIME and had an TIME DATE walk . It was not possible to establish the frequency of family visits or of the applicant 's meetings with counsel . The applicant was also frequently taken out of the cell to see a doctor . Inmates suffering from infectious diseases , such as scabies , tuberculosis , HIV , hepatitis or sexually transmittable diseases , were held separately from other inmates . The applicant was never held together with anyone suffering from scabies or tuberculosis .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he was held in cells CARDINAL . CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL . Cell no . CARDINAL measured QUANTITY m. It was equipped with CARDINAL bunks and housed CARDINAL inmates . Cell no . CARDINAL measured CARDINAL sq . m , was equipped with QUANTITY and housed CARDINAL inmates . Cell no . CARDINAL measured QUANTITY m. It was equipped with CARDINAL bunks and housed CARDINAL to CARDINAL inmates . As the number of bunks was often insufficient , inmates had to take turns to sleep . Punishment cell no . CARDINAL , where the applicant was held alone from CARDINAL to CARDINAL DATE , measured QUANTITY m.

CARDINAL . All cells were insufficiently lit . There was CARDINAL CARDINAL-watt light bulb in each cell . The windows were small . Some of them were broken and inmates had to cover the holes with cloth . There was no forced ventilation and it was extremely hot in DATE and very cold in DATE . The cells were stuffy and smoky .

CARDINAL . Each cell was equipped with a lavatory bowl which had no flush system . This was not separated from the living area and the person using the toilet was in view of the other inmates . The dining table was very close to the toilet .

CARDINAL . The cells swarmed with rats , bugs , lice , spiders and cockroaches . The walls were covered with mould . Articles of hygiene were sparse . The bedding was dirty and ragged . All complaints to the detention facility administration about poor sanitary conditions went unanswered .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant shared his cell with persons suffering from tuberculosis and scabies . He allegedly contracted scabies while in GPE .

CARDINAL . Inmates were allowed to take a shower once DATE . The entire cell population was taken to the shower hall for a total of TIME . There were CARDINAL shower stands and the inmates had insufficient time to shower .

CARDINAL . NORP The food was insipid . There was neither fruit nor meat . Vegetables were rarely served . Fish was served in small quantities of QUANTITY per person per day . Although the applicant was prescribed a special diet by a doctor , no special food was provided .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant submitted written statements by his co - detainees confirming his description of the conditions of detention .

CARDINAL . The applicant attempted to lodge complaints about the appalling conditions with the prosecutor of the NORP region and the head of the penitentiary department of the NORP region . The remand centre administration did not dispatch his complaints . The warders threatened that he would suffer if he attempted to complain again . He was then put in a punishment cell for DATE .

CARDINAL . It appears from the decision of CARDINAL DATE issued by the acting head of remand centre no . IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL that the applicant was put in a punishment cell for wrenching the tap off a drinking water tank and using it to make a hole in the wall through which he communicated with the inmates in the neighbouring cell .
CARDINAL . The applicant also alleged that during the trial he had been regularly transported to the courthouse in inhuman conditions .

CARDINAL . According to a certificate of DATE issued by the remand centre administration and submitted by the ORG , remand centre no . GPE in GPE , where the applicant was held from DATE to CARDINAL DATE , had a medical unit . The medical staff consisted of a general physician , a specialist in skin and venereal diseases , a surgeon , an otolaryngologist , a dentist , a radiologist , a tuberculosis specialist , physician assistants and nurses . The unit had all the necessary equipment and medication .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a physician . He informed the doctor that he had been HIV - positive since DATE and that he was also infected with hepatitis B and C viruses . On DATE he was examined by a psychiatrist who diagnosed him with drug withdrawal syndrome . An HIV antibody blood test confirmed that the applicant was indeed HIV - positive . A chest photofluorography was also performed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a drug addiction specialist from an HIV medical unit . He noted that the disease had attained clinical stage CARDINAL , but that the applicant 's state of health was satisfactory . He prescribed a special diet . He further recommended that the applicant be held in a special cell for HIV - positive inmates and that general blood and urine tests and chest photofluorography be performed DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a psychiatrist . He complained of headache and liver pain . The doctor prescribed a pain reliever and liver pills .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a nurse . He complained of liver pain . The nurse prescribed hepatoprotective herbal pills and antispasmodic pills .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a surgeon . On DATE a chest photofluorography was performed .
CARDINAL . On DATE general blood and urine tests were performed .
CARDINAL . On DATE a hepatitis C antibody blood test confirmed that the applicant was suffering from chronic hepatitis C.
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a psychiatrist .

CARDINAL . On DATE CDCARDINAL , CDCARDINAL and viral load tests were made . The applicant 's CDCARDINAL count was CARDINAL.CARDINAL x CARDINAL ( equivalent to CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL ) , while his HIV RNA ( viral load ) was CARDINAL copies / ml .
CARDINAL . On DATE a nurse explained to the applicant the results of the CDCARDINAL and viral load tests .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was examined by a general physician . He complained of pain in his left shoulder joint . He was diagnosed with arthrosis and prescribed anti - inflammatory treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE a chest photofluorography was performed .

CARDINAL . On DATE CDCARDINAL and viral load tests were made for the second time . The applicant 's CDCARDINAL count was QUANTITY ( equivalent to CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL ) , while his HIV RNA ( viral load ) was CARDINAL copies / ml .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was diagnosed with dermatitis and prescribed treatment for dermatitis and hepatoprotective pills .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained about insomnia and was prescribed sleeping pills .

CARDINAL . At DATE a treatment schedule for DATE was prepared . It was recommended that the applicant should be examined twice a year by a general physician , a tuberculosis specialist and an infectious disease specialist . Chest photofluorography and abdominal ultrasound scans were to be performed twice a year and the applicant was to receive a special diet .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general physician before being transferred to the correctional colony . The examining doctor confirmed the previous diagnosis . On DATE the applicant was transferred to correctional colony no . CARDINAL in the NORP region .
CARDINAL . On DATE general blood and urine tests were performed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by the colony 's physician assistant . He noted that the applicant 's health was satisfactory , his skin was healthy and the lymph nodes were not enlarged .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was admitted to the prison hospital of the NORP region ( no . IK-CARDINAL , hereafter “ NORP prison hospital ” ) . He was examined by a neuropathologist and an ophthalmologist and underwent an abdominal ultrasound scan and a general blood test . The doctors prescribed anti - inflammatory treatment for arthrosis , hepatoprotective pills and vitamins .

DATE . On DATE CDCARDINAL and viral load tests were performed . The applicant 's CDCARDINAL count was CARDINAL x CARDINAL ( equivalent to CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL ) , while his HIV RNA ( viral load ) was CARDINAL copies / ml .
CARDINAL . The applicant was discharged from hospital on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by the colony 's physician assistant . He complained of an aching shoulder joint and liver pains . The physician 's assistant noted that the applicant 's health was satisfactory .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a psychiatrist who diagnosed him with heroin addiction in forced remission .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained of dizziness . He was examined by a nurse who diagnosed him with low blood pressure and prescribed vitamins .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was again examined by the colony 's physician assistant . The applicant again complained of liver pain and an aching shoulder joint . The physician assistant noted that the applicant 's gall bladder was deformed but his health was otherwise satisfactory .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again complained of an aching shoulder joint . He was prescribed pain relievers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was admitted to the surgery unit of NORP prison hospital . His shoulder joint was X - rayed and general blood and urine tests were made . He was diagnosed with arthrosis and prescribed pain relievers and physiotherapy .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was discharged from hospital .

CARDINAL . At DATE a treatment schedule for DATE was prepared . It was noted that the applicant 's HIV condition had attained clinical stage CARDINAL . It was recommended that the applicant be examined DATE by a general physician , a tuberculosis specialist and an infectious disease specialist . He was also to undergo laboratory examinations twice a year , and chest photofluorography and abdominal ultrasound scans were to be performed DATE . The applicant was also to receive a special diet .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was granted disability status .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by the colony 's physician assistant , who found that his health was satisfactory .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was again examined by a physician assistant , who prescribed treatment for a respiratory infection and gum inflammation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a physician . He complained of fever , abdomen pains , cough , headache and heartburn . He was prescribed antibacterial pills .
CARDINAL . On DATE general blood and urine tests were made .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was taken to NORP prison hospital for examination . He was examined by an ophthalmologist , a surgeon , a neuropathologist , a dentist , a psychiatrist and a general physician . He underwent general blood and urine tests , an ultrasound scan of the abdominal area and an electrocardiogram . He received vitamins and neuroleptic drugs .

CARDINAL . On DATE CDCARDINAL and viral load tests were performed . The applicant 's CDCARDINAL count was QUANTITY ( equivalent to CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL ) , while his HIV RNA ( viral load ) was CARDINAL copies / ml .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was discharged from hospital .

CARDINAL . At DATE a treatment schedule for DATE was prepared . It was recommended that the applicant be examined twice a year by a physician , a tuberculosis specialist and an infectious disease specialist . Chest photofluorography , abdominal ultrasound scans and gastro - duodenoscopy were to be performed twice a year and the applicant was to receive a special diet .

DATE . On DATE the applicant was again taken to NORP prison hospital for examination . He was examined by an ophthalmologist , a surgeon , a neuropathologist , a dentist , a psychiatrist , a dermatologist and an otolaryngologist and underwent an ultrasound scan of the abdominal area and a chest photofluorography . General blood and urine tests were also made . He received vitamins and physiotherapy . He was discharged on DATE . The hospital doctors recommended treatment for arthritis and gall bladder deformation and regular supervision by a general physician and a psychiatrist .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a physician assistant , who found that his condition was satisfactory .
CARDINAL . On DATE a hepatitis B antibody blood test was performed which established that the applicant did not have hepatitis B.

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of ORG no . CARDINALFZ of DATE ) provides that detainees should be given free food sufficient to maintain them in good health according to standards established by the Government of GPE . Section CARDINAL provides that detainees should be kept in conditions which satisfy sanitary and hygienic requirements . They should be provided with an individual sleeping place and given bedding , tableware and toiletries . Each inmate should have QUANTITY of personal space in his or her cell .

CARDINAL . NORP law gives detailed guidelines for the provision of medical assistance to detained individuals . These guidelines , found in joint Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG and ORG , on ORG or Detained ( “ the Regulation ” ) , enacted on DATE , are applicable to all detainees without exception . In particular , section III of the Regulation sets out the procedure for initial steps to be taken by medical personnel of a detention facility on admission of a detainee . On arrival at a detention facility all detainees must be subjected to preliminary medical examination before they are placed in cells shared by other inmates . The examination is performed with the aim of identifying individuals suffering from contagious diseases or in need of urgent medical assistance . Particular attention must be paid to individuals suffering from contagious conditions . DATE after the detainee 's arrival at the detention facility , he should receive an in - depth medical examination , including fluorography . During the in - depth examination a doctor should record the detainee 's complaints , study his medical and personal history , record injuries if present , and recent tattoos , and schedule additional medical procedures if necessary . A doctor should also authorise laboratory analyses to identify sexually transmitted diseases , HIV , tuberculosis and other illnesses .

CARDINAL . Subsequent medical examinations of detainees are performed at least twice a DATE or at the detainees ' request . If a detainee 's state of health has deteriorated , medical examinations and assistance should be provided by medical personnel of the detention facility . In such cases a medical examination should include a general medical check - up and additional methods of testing , if necessary , with the participation of particular medical specialists . The results of the examinations should be recorded in the detainee 's medical history . The detainee should be fully informed of the results of the medical examinations .

CARDINAL . Detainees take prescribed medicines in the presence of a doctor . In a limited number of cases the head of the medical department of the detention facility may authorise his medical personnel to hand over a DATE dose of medicines to the detainee for unobserved intake .

CARDINAL . Section X of the Regulation regulates medical examinations , monitoring and treatment of detainees suffering from HIV . In particular , it provides that medical examinations , monitoring and treatment of detainees infected with HIV should be performed in accordance with the general standards of medical assistance to HIV - positive patients . All HIV - positive detainees should be registered and their condition should be monitored regularly to secure timely diagnosis and treatment of diseases that may accelerate the progression of the HIV infection , timely identification of symptoms of such progression and timely prescription of specific therapy . During the initial examination of an HIV - infected detainee a doctor must confirm his HIV status , identify the clinical stage of the disease , detect possible opportunistic infections and set up an adequate course of treatment . The frequency of subsequent medical examinations depends on the clinical stage of the disease and the detainee 's CDCARDINAL count . A detainee in clinical stage CARDINAL of the disease and with a CDCARDINAL count exceeding CARDINAL cells / mm³ must be examined by a doctor DATE , while a detainee in clinical stage CARDINAL of the disease with a CDCARDINAL count lower than CARDINAL cells / mm³ must be examined by a doctor DATE .

DATE . Order no . CARDINAL , on Standard medical assistance to persons infected with HIV , issued by ORG on DATE , provides that a person infected with HIV must be subjected to the following tests and examinations in particular , irrespective of the clinical stage of the disease :
- abdominal ultrasound scan twice a year ;
- electrocardiography DATE ;
- chest photofluorography once or DATE ;
- a general blood test CARDINAL times a year ;
- a general urine test once DATE ;
- psychology consultation CARDINAL times a year ;
- HIV RNA ( viral load ) test twice a year ;
- CDCARDINAL test CARDINAL times a year .
CARDINAL . ORG ( “ WHO ” ) guidelines of DATE “ Antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection in adults and adolescents : recommendations for a public health approach ” read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . Immunological assessment of HIV - infected adults and adolescents

The optimum time to commence ORG [ antiretroviral therapy ] is before patients become unwell or present with their first opportunistic infection . Immunological monitoring ( CDCARDINAL testing ) is the ideal way to approach this situation . A baseline CDCARDINAL cell count not only guides the decision on when to initiate ORG but is also essential if CDCARDINAL counts are to be used to monitor ORG . Table CARDINAL summarizes the immunological criteria for the initiation of ART .
Table CARDINAL . CDCARDINAL criteria for the initiation of ART in adults and adolescents

The benchmark threshold marking a substantially increased risk of clinical disease progression is a CDCARDINAL cell count of CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL . Although it is never too late to initiate ORG , patients should preferably begin the therapy before the CDCARDINAL cell count drops to or QUANTITY . The optimum time to initiate ORG with a CDCARDINAL cell count of CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL is unknown . Patients with CDCARDINAL cell counts in this range require regular clinical and immunological evaluation .

The treatment of patients with WHO clinical stage CARDINAL disease should not depend on a CDCARDINAL cell count determination : all such patients should initiate ORG . For WHO clinical stage CARDINAL conditions , a threshold of QUANTITY has been identified as a level below which functional immune deficiency is present and ORG should be considered ... For patients with clinical stage CARDINAL or CARDINAL disease , a CDCARDINAL count below CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL is a clear indication for treatment . Although there are no randomized trial data on the CDCARDINAL cell count level at which to start therapy in asymptomatic persons , data from a number of cohorts have been consistent in demonstrating that disease progression is greater in persons who start antiretroviral therapy with CDCARDINAL counts CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL than in those starting therapy above this level . In general these studies have not been able to detect a difference in outcome between persons who start therapy at CDCARDINAL counts of CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL and those who do so at CDCARDINAL counts CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL . However , if the CDCARDINAL count is CARDINAL cells / mmCARDINAL , ART should be delayed ...
Table CARDINAL . Recommendations for initiating ORG in adults and adolescents in accordance with clinical stages and the availability of immunological markers
CARDINAL . Virological assessment of HIV - infected adults and adolescents

Plasma viral load measurement is not necessary before initiating ORG . It rarely informs the clinical decision as to when ORG should begin if both PERSON testing and the assessment of clinical staging are performed ...
CARDINAL . Considerations in hepatitis B or hepatitis C coinfection

In the setting of HIV infection the course of ORG [ hepatitis C]-associated liver disease is accelerated . Rates of progression of liver disease in HIV / ORG coinfection are greater . ... there is contradictory evidence on the effects of ORG on HIV disease progression . In the NORP cohort study the presence of ORG was independently associated with an increased risk of progression to AIDS and death . However , the EuroSIDA cohort analysis found that the overall virological and immunological responses to ORG were not affected by ORG serostatus ... However , the risk of mortality related to liver disease was markedly increased in ORG - seropositive patients ...

Irrespective of whether a patient has HIV infection , the optimal treatment for hepatitis C virus infection is pegylated interferon alpha and ribavirin ( ORG ) ... The initiation of LAW in HIV / ORG - coinfected patients should follow the same principles and recommendations as for the initiation of ORG in HIV - monoinfected patients . However , the patients should be followed up more closely because of the major risk of drug - related hepatotoxicity and for specific drug interactions of some ARVs with anti - HCV drugs ... In patients with high CDCARDINAL cell counts it is preferable to treat ORG infection before HIV . While concurrent treatment of both infections is feasible , it may be complicated by pill burden ... , drug toxicities and drug interactions . In patients who need ORG it may be preferable to initiate ORG and delay ORG therapy in order to obtain better anti - HCV response rates after immune recovery ...
CARDINAL . Clinical and laboratory monitoring

Clinical and laboratory monitoring of HIV - infected patients serves CARDINAL purposes . Firstly , for patients under care who are not yet eligible for ORG , regular monitoring is essential for the identification of the point at which they become eligible for ORG or for prophylaxis against opportunistic infections ... Well - designed monitoring protocols can facilitate the initiation of [ opportunistic infections ] prophylaxis and LAW in the majority of HIV - infected patients before they develop advanced HIV infection .
Secondly , once patients have been initiated on ORG , regular monitoring is necessary to assess efficacy , manage side - effects and identify treatment failure ...

Because resources are limited , laboratory testing should generally be directed by signs and symptoms and should be done only when the results can be used to guide management decisions . Exceptions are the recommendations to obtain a CDCARDINAL cell count DATE ...
CARDINAL . Monitoring of patients who are not yet eligible for ART

Patients who are not yet eligible for ORG should be monitored for clinical progression and by CDCARDINAL count measurement DATE . Clinical evaluation should include the same parameters as are used in baseline evaluations , including weight gain or loss and development of clinical signs and symptoms of progressive HIV disease . These clinical parameters and the CDCARDINAL cell count should be used to update the WHO disease stage at each visit and to determine whether patients have become eligible for [ opportunistic infections ] prophylaxis or ORG . Clinical evaluation and CDCARDINAL counts can be obtained more frequently as the clinical or immunological threshold for initiating ORG approaches ( Table CARDINAL ) ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE WHO published a document entitled “ Rapid Advice : Antiretroviral Therapy for HIV Infection in Adults and Adolescents ” . It revised the previous recommendations concerning the commencement of antiretroviral treatment contained in the DATE guidelines . It strongly recommended that antiretroviral treatment be started in all patients with HIV who had a CDCARDINAL count lower than CARDINAL cells per mmCARDINAL irrespective of clinical symptoms . It stressed the necessity of CDCARDINAL testing in identifying whether HIV - positive patients at WHO clinical stage CARDINAL or CARDINAL of the disease needed to start antiretroviral treatment . Furthermore , it strongly recommended that antiretroviral treatment be started in all patients with HIV at WHO clinical stage CARDINAL or CARDINAL irrespective of CDCARDINAL count .
CARDINAL . The same recommendations are contained in the ORG 's DATE guidelines “ Antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection in adults and adolescents : recommendations for a public health approach ” .
